title: Having a row or asking for directions?
intro: If two people are talking lively and you don't understand their culture or their language, you might think they are having an argument. Neil and Tim talk about this kind of situation and teach you six items of vocabulary.
this_week_question: In which country does shaking your head mean ‘yes’, Tim? Is it…
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: is something you say to somebody you have argued with or beaten in a game or contest to say you’d still like to be friends
to argue or disagree with them
a movement you make with your hands or head to express what you are thinking or feeling
saying or doing something embarrassing in a social situation
to make somebody angry or upset
showing what you think or feel

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Welcome to 6 Minute English. In this programme we bring you an expressive topic and six items of vocabulary. I’m Neil…

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: And I’m Tim. So, we had an argument just before we started the show… Neil We did, Tim. But no hard feelings?

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: None. No hard feelings is something you say to somebody you have argued with to say you’d still like to be friends. We often fall out over silly things…

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: … Like who’s going to introduce the show…

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: … Or who’s going to choose the quiz question.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: But we understand each other. That’s the important thing, isn't it? To fall out with somebody by the way, is another way of saying to argue or disagree with them. Do you know that you wave your arms around a lot when you’re arguing, Tim?

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: No, I didn’t know I did that.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: That isn’t very British.

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: I know. Using gestures – or movements you make with your hands or your head to express what you are thinking of feeling – is common in some countries but not in others. Then there are some movements – like shaking your head – which mostly means ‘no’ but in some countries can mean the opposite.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: That’s right. In which country does shaking your head mean ‘yes’, Tim? Is it… a) Greece, b) Japan or c) Bulgaria?

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: No idea – I’ll guess Greece. I do know that in India people shake their heads to mean lots of different things.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: There are plenty of gestures you need to be careful with when you’re meeting and greeting people from a culture that’s different to your own – to avoid offending people – or making an awkward faux pas…

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: If you make a faux pas it means you say or do something embarrassing in a social situation. For example, our every day use of the thumbs-up signal might offend people from the Middle East.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And to offend means to make somebody angry or upset.

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: Let’s hear now from Business Professor Erin Meyer talking about how easy it is to misunderstand why people behave the way they do in everyday situations when we don’t belong to the same culture.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Erin Meyer, Business Professor in Dubai A while ago I was in Dubai and one of my students, my Emirati students, was driving me home after a session and the car stopped at a light and she rolled down the window, and she started shouting at someone outside of the window. This guy was crossing the street with a big box of cloth. And he started shouting back, and she opened up the door, and they started gesticulating and shouting at one another. And I thought, wow, they’re having a huge fight, I thought maybe he was going to hit her. And she got back in the car, and I said, well, what were you fighting about? And she said, ‘Oh no, no, we weren’t fighting, he was giving me directions to your hotel.’ And I thought that was a great example of how someone from another culture may misperceive or misunderstand something as a fight when in fact they were just being emotionally expressive.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Gesticulating – what does that mean?

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: It means what I was doing earlier! – Waving your arms around to express what you’re feeling.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Erin Meyer was worried because her student and the man on the street were shouting and gesticulating at each other. She thought they were having a fight when in fact they were just being emotionally expressive.

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: And expressive means showing what you think or feel.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: You were nodding in agreement, there, Tim. Which reminds me of our quiz question. In which country does shaking your head mean ‘yes’? Is it… a) Greece, b) Japan or c) Bulgaria?

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: I said Greece…

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And that’s the wrong answer, I’m afraid. The right answer is Bulgaria. In some Southeastern European areas such as Bulgaria and southern Albania, shaking your head is used to indicate "yes". In those regions, nodding in fact means "no" as well.

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: I hope I remember that the next time I meet somebody from Southeastern Europe. OK, shall we look back at the words we learned today?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: ‘No hard feelings’ is something you say to somebody you have argued with or beaten in a game or contest to say you’d still like to be friends.

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: For example, “I always get the quiz questions right – unlike you Neil. But no hard feelings, OK?”

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: That’s not a very realistic example, Tim… But I’ll let it go. Number two – ‘to fall out with somebody’ means to argue or disagree with them.

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: “I fell out with my best friend at school. We didn’t talk to each other for a whole week!”

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: That must’ve been a serious disagreement, Tim! What were you arguing about? Tim I can’t remember. It was a long time ago. Number three – a ‘gesture’ is a movement you make with your hands or head to express what you are thinking or feeling.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: “She opened her arms wide in a gesture of welcome.”

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: Or the verb – “I gestured to Neil that we only had one minute left to finish the show!”

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Is that true, Tim? You’re nodding your head – but we should also quickly mention ‘gesticulate’ which means to make gestures with your hands or arms!

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: A ‘faux pas’ is saying or doing something embarrassing in a social situation. For example, “I committed a serious faux pas at a party last night – that I’m too embarrassed to tell you about!”

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Oh dear, Tim. I hope you didn’t offend too many people – ‘offend’ is our next word – and it means to make somebody angry or upset.

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: Well, you’ve given us a good example already, Neil, so let’s move on to the final word – ‘expressive’ – which means showing what you think or feel.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: “Tim has a very expressive face.”

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: Thanks! Another quick example – “I waved my hand expressively to signal to Neil that it was time to finish the show.”

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Taking my cue from Tim, that’s all for today. But please remember to check out our Instagram, Twitter, Facebook and YouTube pages.

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: Bye-bye!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Goodbye!
